2018-04-01.abstract: Carl Hoffman’s “The Last Wild Men of Borneo” tells the stories of an environmental activist accepted by an indigenous tribe and a man who became one of the world’s most successful tribal-art collectors.
2018-04-01.snippet: Carl Hoffman’s “The Last Wild Men of Borneo” tells the stories of an environmental activist accepted by an indigenous tribe and a man who became one of the world’s most successful tribal-art collectors.
2018-04-01.lead_paragraph: Bruno Manser and Michael Palmieri went to Borneo, the third-largest island on the planet, seeking different things. Starting in the mid-1980s, Manser, a Swiss traveler, decided to live with the Penan, an indigenous tribe that eventually accepted him as one of its own. After several years with the Penan, Manser became an outspoken critic of deforestation on the island, and he disappeared in 2000, presumed dead. Mr. Palmieri, a Californian, eventually settled in Bali, and from there took a series of trips to Borneo seeking art and artifacts that he sold to museums and collectors. In “The Last Wild Men of Borneo,” Carl Hoffman, himself an adventurer-journalist, tells their stories. Like Manser and Mr. Palmieri, Hoffman has long harbored a fascination with Borneo. Its “forest and its people were the very definition of exotic in the Western mind,” he writes. Mr. Hoffman’s 2014 book, “Savage Harvest,” was an account of the disappearance of Nelson Rockefeller’s son Michael in New Guinea. Below, Mr. Hoffman discusses how that book led to this one, the way his view of his subjects changed over time and more.
2018-04-01.headline_main: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: Two Adventurers on Very Different Missions to Borneo

Many had been awaiting the decision for years; the alert, one of several hundreds The Times will send this year, took readers straight to the breaking news on nytimes.com.

2018-04-01.abstract: Fifty years after King’s assassination, three television documentaries explore his impact on the nightly news, and King’s more disillusioned final years.
2018-04-01.snippet: Fifty years after King’s assassination, three television documentaries explore his impact on the nightly news, and King’s more disillusioned final years.
2018-04-01.lead_paragraph: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., more than most civil rights leaders, understood the singular role that television played in documenting the brutality of racial violence on African-Americans and eliciting sympathy from white viewers. As three new television documentaries marking the 50th anniversary of his assassination show, King embraced prime time news television coverage as a matter of political strategy and survival through his savvy use of sound bites, well-timed protests and the practice of nonviolence in the face of abuse.
2018-04-01.headline_main: Seeing Martin Luther King Jr. in a New Light

2018-04-01.lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Ebert kept small stacks of paper in every room of the farmhouse — just in case. She wrote whenever the rhymes blossomed: sometimes in the middle of the night, sometimes at the chirp of dawn, sometimes in the summer fallow tractor, where she’d draw a finger across the dusty windshield.
2018-04-01.headline_main: Elizabeth Ebert, ‘Grand Dame of Cowboy Poetry,’ Dies at 93

2018-04-01.abstract: His appeal to “forgotten” Americans is one of many parallels linking Mr. Wallace, remembered for conservatism and opposition to integration, to the trajectory of Donald J. Trump.
2018-04-01.snippet: His appeal to “forgotten” Americans is one of many parallels linking Mr. Wallace, remembered for conservatism and opposition to integration, to the trajectory of Donald J. Trump.
2018-04-01.lead_paragraph: Separated by as much as half a century, the two men’s public lives run strikingly parallel. It’s as if they drank from the same political cup: George C. Wallace, the Alabama governor who ached to become president, and Donald J. Trump, the developer and showman who made it to the top. They are bound by their streaks of opportunism and by their campaigns tailored to resentful voters brimming with the conviction that society’s deck is stacked against them.
2018-04-01.headline_main: George Wallace Tapped Into Racial Fear. Decades Later, Its Force Remains Potent.

2018-04-01.abstract: New York’s humor and creativity were on full display at the annual Easter Parade and Easter Bonnet Festival on Sunday.
2018-04-01.snippet: New York’s humor and creativity were on full display at the annual Easter Parade and Easter Bonnet Festival on Sunday.
2018-04-01.lead_paragraph: Martin Burke and Autumn Ward stood on Sunday in front of St. Patrick’s Cathedral in Manhattan and struck poses for the dozens of spectators taking photographs of them. Mr. Burke wore a dapper suit and Ms. Ward a bright floral dress. The cameras, however, were pointed at the couple’s headwear: papier-mâché versions of the stone moai heads of Easter Island.
2018-04-01.headline_main: Only in New York: Easter Parade With Moai Heads and a Kraken

2018-04-01.abstract: People are increasingly calling for boycotts of the big tech companies amid a backlash. The problem is that Facebook, Apple, Amazon and Google are nearly inescapable.
2018-04-01.snippet: People are increasingly calling for boycotts of the big tech companies amid a backlash. The problem is that Facebook, Apple, Amazon and Google are nearly inescapable.
2018-04-01.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Ryan Knight, a Democratic activist in Los Angeles, called for a boycott of Apple in February because it hadn’t responded to calls to delete a channel from the National Rifle Association from its streaming-video service after the Parkland, Fla., school shooting.
2018-04-01.headline_main: They Tried to Boycott Facebook, Apple and Google. They Failed.

2018-04-01.headline_main: Tech Thinks It Has a Fix for the Problems It Created: Blockchain

2018-04-01.abstract: Much of rural America will abandon the president if his tariffs incite a crisis for rural businesses.
2018-04-01.snippet: Much of rural America will abandon the president if his tariffs incite a crisis for rural businesses.
2018-04-01.lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Iowa — Donald Trump won over 60 percent of the 2016 vote in rural Iowa, where I live, and I haven’t heard much concern from Republicans over the president’s alleged infidelities with a porn actress, his ties to Russia or Jared Kushner’s real estate shenanigans.
2018-04-01.headline_main: Will Trump Crash the Farm Economy?

2018-04-01.abstract: Americans should be able to control their personal information, too.
2018-04-01.snippet: Americans should be able to control their personal information, too.
2018-04-01.lead_paragraph: “We have a responsibility to protect your information,” Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Facebook, declared recently in a full-page newspaper advertisement. “If we can’t, we don’t deserve it.”
2018-04-01.headline_main: Can Europe Lead on Privacy?

2018-04-01.abstract: We all want our children to have a better life than we did. But statistics say they won’t.
2018-04-01.snippet: We all want our children to have a better life than we did. But statistics say they won’t.
2018-04-01.lead_paragraph: Daddy lives in a quiet corner of Virginia, on the same country road his grandmother walked in the early 1900s. Recently, he shared with me some writings he’s been keeping for years — little remembrances, ideas about what constitutes a loving family, what makes a man. One of the essays describes the day his mother died.
2018-04-01.headline_main: A New Black American Dream

2018-04-01.abstract: The Yankees chose to pitch to Smoak instead of Josh Donaldson in the eighth inning, a decision that led to a game-changing home run for Toronto.
2018-04-01.snippet: The Yankees chose to pitch to Smoak instead of Josh Donaldson in the eighth inning, a decision that led to a game-changing home run for Toronto.
2018-04-01.lead_paragraph: TORONTO — With Toronto Blue Jays at second and third, two outs in the eighth inning and the Yankees clinging to a one-run lead, Manager Aaron Boone and the pitching coach Larry Rothschild looked to the mound from their perch on the dugout railing and gestured to reliever David Robertson.
2018-04-01.headline_main: Justin Smoak Punishes Yankees, and Aaron Boone, With a Grand Slam

2018-04-01.abstract: In a crowded marketplace, fonts can help a company stand out — provided it knows what it’s trying to communicate and who it’s trying to reach.
2018-04-01.snippet: In a crowded marketplace, fonts can help a company stand out — provided it knows what it’s trying to communicate and who it’s trying to reach.
2018-04-01.lead_paragraph: When ads for the Netflix show “Stranger Things” first appeared in 2016, the glowing, blood-red, unevenly shaded font that spelled out the title told viewers exactly what they could expect. The retro typeface — and a haunting, one-minute title video — became synonymous with the supernatural thriller series and, as the show gained in popularity, memes centered largely on its instantly recognizable title have become plentiful.
2018-04-01.headline_main: Gothic or Helvetica? For Brands, Fonts Help Tell a Story

2018-04-01.abstract: An operation to smear a nerve agent on Sergei Skripal’s door handle was so risky, it is unlikely to have been tried without Kremlin approval, British officials investigating the case believe.
2018-04-01.snippet: An operation to smear a nerve agent on Sergei Skripal’s door handle was so risky, it is unlikely to have been tried without Kremlin approval, British officials investigating the case believe.
2018-04-01.lead_paragraph: LONDON — British officials investigating the poisoning of Sergei V. Skripal, a former Russian double agent, believe it is likely that an assassin smeared a nerve agent on the door handle at his home. This operation is seen as so risky and sensitive that it is unlikely to have been undertaken without approval from the Kremlin, according to officials who have been briefed on the early findings of the inquiry.
2018-04-01.headline_main: Poisoned Door Handle Hints at High-Level Plot to Kill Spy, U.K. Officials Say

2018-04-01.abstract: Mark Peterson, the photographer who worked on a story for The Magazine about the secretary of defense, describes how he captured the press-averse official.
2018-04-01.snippet: Mark Peterson, the photographer who worked on a story for The Magazine about the secretary of defense, describes how he captured the press-averse official.
2018-04-01.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary James Mattis declined to sit for a portrait for Sunday’s New York Times Magazine cover story, “Last Man Standing,” by Robert F. Worth. So to provide readers with an original image of Mr. Mattis, the magazine needed to photograph the secretary during his limited public appearances, which happen about once a week when he briefly walks down the Pentagon steps to welcome visiting dignitaries.For the assignment, the magazine enlisted the photographer Mark Peterson, a contributor to The Times for over 20 years, who is known for his skill at capturing candid shots that tell a full story. Mr. Peterson took the picture that would become Sunday’s cover of The Times Magazine on his second trip to the Pentagon for this assignment, as Mr. Mattis met with the defense minister of Estonia in early March. Mr. Peterson recently explained how he got the shot.
2018-04-01.headline_main: How a Photographer Got a Rare Shot of James Mattis

2018-04-01.abstract: If we learn anything from the recent controversies surrounding the social media giant, it should be that America’s privacy laws need beefing up.
2018-04-01.snippet: If we learn anything from the recent controversies surrounding the social media giant, it should be that America’s privacy laws need beefing up.
2018-04-01.lead_paragraph: As recently as 2010, Mark Zuckerberg, the founder and chief executive of Facebook, believed that privacy was no longer a “social norm.” But over the past few weeks — and not a moment too soon — he and his colleagues have learned that privacy still matters to individuals and society.
2018-04-01.headline_main: Facebook Is Not the Problem. Lax Privacy Rules Are.

2018-04-02.abstract: Iran froze its nuclear program after months of talks. If Trump kills that deal, Kim Jong-un will see little reason to trust him in negotiations.
2018-04-02.snippet: Iran froze its nuclear program after months of talks. If Trump kills that deal, Kim Jong-un will see little reason to trust him in negotiations.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: As he prepares for possible talks with the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un about controlling the North’s nuclear weapons program, President Trump is facing his most complicated national security challenge so far. He has made the task far harder by threatening to blow up the only other recent deal to control a nuclear program, with Iran.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Trump’s Iran Threat May Wreck Talks With North Korea

2018-04-02.abstract: Ogunbowale hit a 3-pointer with 0.1 of a second left to give the Irish its first championship since 2001.
2018-04-02.snippet: Ogunbowale hit a 3-pointer with 0.1 of a second left to give the Irish its first championship since 2001.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Of course it ended this way: nothing easily won, no breathing room, nothing decided until the final second, and then the great release of victory.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Notre Dame’s Arike Ogunbowale Beats Buzzer — Again — to Give Irish the Title

2018-04-02.abstract: After teasing “important news” to come, he tweeted: “Tesla has gone completely and totally bankrupt. So bankrupt, you can’t believe it.”
2018-04-02.snippet: After teasing “important news” to come, he tweeted: “Tesla has gone completely and totally bankrupt. So bankrupt, you can’t believe it.”
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: For the past week, as the electric-car maker Tesla has been buffeted by a barrage of negative news, Elon Musk, its chief executive, has offered no public comments on the company’s shaky finances, its slumping stock price or the increasing questions about the safety of its self-driving technology.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Elon Musk Makes Light of Tesla’s Troubles in April Fool’s Tweets

2018-04-02.abstract: A two-pronged strategy contained in the state budget seeks to minimize the impact of the new federal cap on deductions of state and local taxes.
2018-04-02.snippet: A two-pronged strategy contained in the state budget seeks to minimize the impact of the new federal cap on deductions of state and local taxes.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: As many New Yorkers try to figure out how painful a hit they will take from the new federal cap on state and local tax deductions, the budget that passed in Albany on Saturday arrived with glimmers of hope shrouded in even more uncertainty.
2018-04-02.headline_main: New York Crafts Loophole to Protect Property Tax Deductions. But the I.R.S. Could Close It.

2018-04-02.abstract: Bucking a global trend, Uzbekistan’s new leader is reining in the secret police, releasing political prisoners and allowing some freedom of expression.
2018-04-02.snippet: Bucking a global trend, Uzbekistan’s new leader is reining in the secret police, releasing political prisoners and allowing some freedom of expression.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: TASHKENT, Uzbekistan — Unraveling a police state is never easy, and just how fraught the process can be has been playing out in a basement cell in Uzbekistan, a rare example of a country seeking to tame a vicious security apparatus at a time when many other nations are doing the opposite.
2018-04-02.headline_main: As Authoritarianism Spreads, Uzbekistan Goes the Other Way

2018-04-02.abstract: These shootings keep happening because, on some level, America finds them acceptable.
2018-04-02.snippet: These shootings keep happening because, on some level, America finds them acceptable.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — As the California sun burned away the haze on Easter Eve, a few hundred people gathered at yet another rally for Stephon Clark at the picturesque Cesar E. Chavez Plaza across from City Hall.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Stephon Clark: Rhythms of Tragedy

2018-04-02.abstract: In a tight labor market, positions in poultry plants and lumber mills can be tough to fill. But that spells opportunity for recruiters like Ray Wiley.

2018-04-02.abstract: China lost control of the craft in 2016, and sky watchers had been waiting months for it to re-enter the atmosphere, unsure where or when it would land.
2018-04-02.snippet: China lost control of the craft in 2016, and sky watchers had been waiting months for it to re-enter the atmosphere, unsure where or when it would land.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: A Chinese space station the size of a school bus re-entered Earth’s atmosphere about 5:16 p.m. Pacific time on Sunday, scattering its remaining pieces over the southern Pacific Ocean, according to the United States’ Joint Force Space Component Command.

2018-04-02.abstract: There’s respect buried somewhere in the begrudging recognition Negan and Jadis share of each other’s humanity.
2018-04-02.snippet: There’s respect buried somewhere in the begrudging recognition Negan and Jadis share of each other’s humanity.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Although some critics refer to it as the “Disney Death,” that old trick of seemingly killing off characters only to revive them hastily will soon be more closely associated with “The Walking Dead” if things keep on at the current rate. Last week’s installment did not include a title card emblazoned with the words “Now, Henry is dead,” but it did show young Henry getting trampled, characters looking for him and a somber aerial shot of a graveyard. All signs indicated that the boy had passed on to the next life, but this week’s episode had other plans.
2018-04-02.headline_main: ‘The Walking Dead’ Season 8, Episode 14: Resurrection

2018-04-02.abstract: The Chinese Ministry of Commerce announced duties of up to 25 percent on American goods, including pork, retaliating against steel and aluminum tariffs.
2018-04-02.snippet: The Chinese Ministry of Commerce announced duties of up to 25 percent on American goods, including pork, retaliating against steel and aluminum tariffs.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese government hit back Monday at President Trump’s tariffs on steel and aluminum by acting on a threat to put tariffs as high as 25 percent on imports of 128 American-made products, including pork and seamless steel pipes.
2018-04-02.headline_main: China Slaps Tariffs on 128 U.S. Products, Including Wine, Pork and Pipes

2018-04-02.abstract: What are the chances Axe can actually keep his hand out of the cookie jar?
2018-04-02.snippet: What are the chances Axe can actually keep his hand out of the cookie jar?
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Live like a king. It’s a phrase that connotes wealth, luxury, excess, a life of unlimited possibility and security. How easy it is to let the sparkle of the crown jewels blind us to the dead enemies and discarded undesirables through which they were purchased. This week’s episode of “Billions” reminds us, as bluntly as the show ever has, that the games played by Bobby Axelrod and his billionaire boys club in order to remain comfortable on their thrones can have as steep a cost to bystanders as to any player in the game.
2018-04-02.headline_main: ‘Billions’ Season 3, Episode 2 Recap: That Feeling in Your Stomach

2018-04-02.abstract: James Fletcher Chase is in town to solve Paul’s disappearance. He has a briefcase full of dollars, and he knows how to kill a man with a pencil.
2018-04-02.snippet: James Fletcher Chase is in town to solve Paul’s disappearance. He has a briefcase full of dollars, and he knows how to kill a man with a pencil.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: If Episode 1 of “Trust” was an introduction to J. Paul Getty — his disappointment in his children, his emotional repression, his lavish yet frugal life — Episode 2 is a showcase of James Fletcher Chace (Brendan Fraser), the security specialist and former C.I.A. operative Getty sends to Rome to solve the kidnapping of his grandson in the summer of 1973. There’s hardly a moment when Chace is not onscreen, so if you liked this episode, it’s probably because you fell for Fraser’s quirky depiction of him.
2018-04-02.headline_main: ‘Trust’ Season 1, Episode 2 Recap: Don’t Mess With Texas

2018-04-02.abstract: The decisive victory by Carlos Alvarado Quesada, a former labor minister, turns back the upstart Fabricio Alvarado Muñoz, an evangelical Christian singer.
2018-04-02.snippet: The decisive victory by Carlos Alvarado Quesada, a former labor minister, turns back the upstart Fabricio Alvarado Muñoz, an evangelical Christian singer.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A former labor minister and novelist from the governing party was decisively elected president of Costa Rica in a runoff on Sunday, holding off an evangelical Christian singer who had built an upstart campaign in part on his opposition to same-sex marriage.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Costa Rica Election Hands Presidency to Governing Party Stalwart

2018-04-02.abstract: The Selous Game Reserve in central Tanzania is one of Africa’s last, great, uninhabited safari areas, delivering all the big game without the big (human) crowds.
2018-04-02.snippet: The Selous Game Reserve in central Tanzania is one of Africa’s last, great, uninhabited safari areas, delivering all the big game without the big (human) crowds.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Few wildlife parks in Africa allow you to drift lazily along a calm stretch of water like something out of “The African Queen” and take in an incredible amount of wildlife from a boat. The Selous Game Reserve, a remote and spectacular wildlife refuge in central Tanzania, is one of them.
2018-04-02.headline_main: A Family Adventure in the Wild Heart of Tanzania

2018-04-02.abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

2018-04-02.snippet: In the wake of mass shootings, a lifetime of gun ownership leads to unsettling questions.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Two weeks before Christmas, I had a 9-millimeter pistol concealed in my waistband and a rifle with two 30-round magazines in the passenger seat beside me. I was driving down from the mountains to meet a fellow I didn’t know at a Cracker Barrel off I-40 in the North Carolina foothills. He was looking to buy a Kel-Tec Sub-2000, and I had one for sale. Other than that, I didn’t know him from Adam except for a few messages back and forth on Facebook.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Gun Culture Is My Culture. And I Fear for What It Has Become.

2018-04-02.abstract: On a trip from Iraqi Kurdistan to Sinjar, Alissa J. Rubin encountered an unsettling number of checkpoints that made travel nearly impossible.
2018-04-02.snippet: On a trip from Iraqi Kurdistan to Sinjar, Alissa J. Rubin encountered an unsettling number of checkpoints that made travel nearly impossible.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Few American reporters have spent more time reporting from Iraq in the last 15 years than Alissa J. Rubin, who served as both a correspondent and the Baghdad bureau chief for The New York Times at the height of the conflict. Rubin returned to Iraq in 2014 to cover the rise of the Islamic State and was severely injured in a helicopter crash on Mount Sinjar while reporting on targeted attacks against the Yazidi population. She once again returned to the region in January 2018 for a coming article in The Times Magazine. On a drive to the Iraq-Syria border during her last trip, Rubin found that competing military and militia groups had set up checkpoints everywhere, making travel increasingly difficult. The following is an account of the nine hours it took her and her companions to drive 130 miles through more than 26 checkpoints.
2018-04-02.headline_main: In Iraq, I Found Checkpoints as Endless as the Whims of Armed Men

2018-04-02.abstract: A real estate developer-in-training finds a home in Hudson Yards, the largest construction site in the city.
2018-04-02.snippet: A real estate developer-in-training finds a home in Hudson Yards, the largest construction site in the city.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: When touring a potential apartment, many New Yorkers would be alarmed to see a construction shed next door, let alone a demolition site in the backyard. 2018-04-02.headline_main: A Would-Be Developer Chooses a Neighborhood Under Construction

2018-04-02.abstract: Even here in Tennessee’s gun country, keeping armed people out of schools is not too much to ask.
2018-04-02.snippet: Even here in Tennessee’s gun country, keeping armed people out of schools is not too much to ask.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — I didn’t attend the local rally against gun violence on March 24, though more than 10,000 Nashvillians did. The march was planned by Abby Brafman, a Vanderbilt University freshman and 2017 graduate of Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla. I had out-of-town family visiting, so my husband, a high school English teacher, marched alone. A few minutes after he got to the rally, he texted me a photo he’d taken of himself standing in front of another marcher’s sign. It read, “Am I next?” For just a second, I couldn’t breathe.
2018-04-02.headline_main: There Is a Middle Ground on Guns

2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: For many years, the United States has lived under a broad consensus that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is a national hero, even a national saint. Near the end of his life, only a third of the public viewed him positively, according to a 1966 Gallup poll.

2018-04-02.headline_main: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela Is Dead at 81; Fought Apartheid

2018-04-02.abstract: Take the time to make a platter of country captain, or riff off of a new Nigella Lawson recipe for roasted sausages with onions and apples.
2018-04-02.snippet: Take the time to make a platter of country captain, or riff off of a new Nigella Lawson recipe for roasted sausages with onions and apples.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Good morning. Our erstwhile colleague and forever friend Nigella Lawson has a new cookbook coming out of the publishing oven soon, “At My Table: A Celebration of Home Cooking.” One of the things I like about it is how deeply she resents the need to say how many people each dish will feed. “When having people over to eat,” she writes, “I am always stricken with fear that there won’t be enough food; there are always leftovers.”
2018-04-02.headline_main: O Captain! My Captain!

2018-04-02.abstract: Ramon and Audrey take some time off from their respective forms of martyrdom.
2018-04-02.snippet: Ramon and Audrey take some time off from their respective forms of martyrdom.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Finally, Duc Bayer-Boatwright gets his moment in the sun. Don’t get too excited; it’s not that he has a psychological breakthrough or stops being a jerk or even has a particularly substantial story line in this week’s episode of “Here and Now.” For the second week in a row, he’s gritting his teeth through a colitis flare-up — and Ramon’s poop jokes aren’t helping. Duc’s big scene takes place during a hike with his love interest, Carmen. Doubled over in pain, he gets so frantic about finding a place to relieve himself that he falls down a hill and exits the date in an ambulance.
2018-04-02.headline_main: ‘Here and Now’ Season 1, Episode 8: The Absurdist Hero

2018-04-02.abstract: The Defense Ministry said helicopters had targeted members of the Taliban who were planning an attack, but witnesses said there were civilians among the victims.
2018-04-02.snippet: The Defense Ministry said helicopters had targeted members of the Taliban who were planning an attack, but witnesses said there were civilians among the victims.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan military helicopters bombed a religious gathering in the northern province of Kunduz on Monday, killing at least 70 people and wounding 30 others, according to a local official in the area.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Afghan Military Strike Kills at Least 70 at Mosque

2018-04-02.abstract: We’ll be taking a semi-break from April 2-6 this year, but we’ve left you with many ideas for celebrating the season.
2018-04-02.snippet: We’ll be taking a semi-break from April 2-6 this year, but we’ve left you with many ideas for celebrating the season.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Welcome to the new season — even if it looks more like this outside your window right now than this.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Earth Day, Poetry Month, Baseball Season and More: Teaching and Learning About Spring With The New York Times

2018-04-02.abstract: Kupchak, the longtime Los Angeles Lakers executive, could soon go to work for the Michael Jordan-owned Charlotte Hornets.
2018-04-02.snippet: Kupchak, the longtime Los Angeles Lakers executive, could soon go to work for the Michael Jordan-owned Charlotte Hornets.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: The Charlotte Hornets have formally offered their vacant general manager position to the longtime Los Angeles Lakers executive Mitch Kupchak, according to three people with knowledge of the offer.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Hornets Offer G.M. Post to Mitch Kupchak

2018-04-02.abstract: A roomy tote bag reminds her of the importance of a friend — and her Maryland hometown.
2018-04-02.snippet: A roomy tote bag reminds her of the importance of a friend — and her Maryland hometown.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: In this series for T, Emily Spivack, the author of “Worn Stories,” interviews creative types about their most prized possessions. Here, the itinerant singer and songwriter Kelela explains how a bag from her friend, the 2017 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund award-winning designer Telfar Clemens, buoys her when she’s on the move.
2018-04-02.headline_main: The Singer Kelela on Her Favorite Possession

2018-04-02.abstract: Tracy Morgan and Tiffany Haddish are well-paired in this TBS comedy about an ex-con making up for lost time, but the series has an identity crisis.
2018-04-02.snippet: Tracy Morgan and Tiffany Haddish are well-paired in this TBS comedy about an ex-con making up for lost time, but the series has an identity crisis.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: “The Last O.G.” is a time-travel comedy. It just happens that Tray (Tracy Morgan) undertook his journey, from 2002 to 2017, in real time, while sitting in a prison cell.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Review: ‘The Last O.G.’ Searches for Brooklyn, and Itself

2018-04-02.abstract: This Moroccan ritual, now widely popular in Israel but little known in America, offers a spread of sweets including a stacked cake called moufleta.
2018-04-02.snippet: This Moroccan ritual, now widely popular in Israel but little known in America, offers a spread of sweets including a stacked cake called moufleta.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: For American Jews who can’t go too long without their favorite carbohydrates, the end of Passover offers nearly as much cause for celebration as the holiday itself. Many begin right at sundown, wolfing down pizzas. Then come the brownies or other foods with the leavening ingredients they have been avoiding in a nod to ancestors who had no time to let bread dough rise while fleeing Egypt.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Celebrating Mimouna and Its Dose of Post-Passover Carbs

2018-04-02.abstract: These lavish Old Hollywood spectacles will have you singing and dancing along to some of cinema’s greatest show tunes. See all the titles in this collection on Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site.
2018-04-02.snippet: These lavish Old Hollywood spectacles will have you singing and dancing along to some of cinema’s greatest show tunes. See all the titles in this collection on Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: These lavish Old Hollywood spectacles will have you singing and dancing along to some of cinema’s greatest show tunes. See all the titles in this collection on Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site.

2018-04-02.abstract: A look at one of the most revealed entries in the past week’s crossword puzzles.
2018-04-02.snippet: A look at one of the most revealed entries in the past week’s crossword puzzles.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — The Greek mythological character Niobe was the subject of a tough clue from the March 28 crossword puzzle by Peter Gordon: “‘Like ___, all tears’: Hamlet.”
2018-04-02.headline_main: What the Heck Is That?: NIOBE

2018-04-02.abstract: Justice Sotomayor issued an impassioned dissent, saying the majority had told officers that they can “shoot first and think later.”
2018-04-02.snippet: Justice Sotomayor issued an impassioned dissent, saying the majority had told officers that they can “shoot first and think later.”
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday ruled for an Arizona police officer who shot a woman outside her home in Tucson. The court’s decision was unsigned and issued without full briefing and oral argument, an indication that the majority found the case to be easy.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Supreme Court Rules for Police Officer in Excessive Force Case

2018-04-02.abstract: A wave of walkouts and rallies in red states has been organized largely by ordinary teachers.
2018-04-02.snippet: A wave of walkouts and rallies in red states has been organized largely by ordinary teachers.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Thousands of teachers in Oklahoma and Kentucky walked off the job Monday morning, shutting down school districts as they protested cuts in pay, benefits and school funding in a movement that has spread rapidly since igniting in West Virginia this year.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Teachers in Oklahoma and Kentucky Walk Out: ‘It Really Is a Wildfire’

2018-04-02.abstract: While other men accused of sexual harassment lie low, the celebrity chef is already exploring whether he can move on to a new role.
2018-04-02.snippet: While other men accused of sexual harassment lie low, the celebrity chef is already exploring whether he can move on to a new role.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: On a gloomy Friday afternoon in February, Mario Batali sat down for coffee at the Marlton Hotel, a few blocks from Babbo, his restaurant in Greenwich Village. His guest was the food consultant and writer Christine Muhlke.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Disgraced by Scandal, Mario Batali Is Eyeing His Second Act

2018-04-02.abstract: The city’s plan to build a jail in the once-blighted neighborhood is a key step to closing Rikers Island, but its future neighbors are concerned.
2018-04-02.snippet: The city’s plan to build a jail in the once-blighted neighborhood is a key step to closing Rikers Island, but its future neighbors are concerned.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: In the shadow of the Bruckner Expressway in the South Bronx, behind a metal fence topped with barbed wire, is a tow pound with a pivotal role in the city’s campaign to close the notorious jail complex on Rikers Island.
2018-04-02.headline_main: In a Changing South Bronx, Residents See New Jail as Step Backward

2018-04-02.abstract: Francine Segan, author of “Shakespeare’s Kitchen: Renaissance Recipes for the Contemporary Cook,” will discuss Elizabethan food at the 92nd Street Y.
2018-04-02.snippet: Francine Segan, author of “Shakespeare’s Kitchen: Renaissance Recipes for the Contemporary Cook,” will discuss Elizabethan food at the 92nd Street Y.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Elizabethan food, the victuals that fattened Falstaff, will be covered in a talk on April 23, the Bard’s birthday, by Francine Segan, the author of “Shakespeare’s Kitchen: Renaissance Recipes for the Contemporary Cook.” Dining habits will also be covered, and there will be a dish to sample: “Shakespeare’s Kitchen: Elizabethan Daily Life in Food,” April 23 at 7 p.m., $45, 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue (92nd Street), 212-415-5500, 92Y.org.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Talking About Fowl and Fruits on the Bard’s Table

2018-04-02.abstract: “The Recovering” is about romanticizing the “unhinged sparks of luminous chaos” in artists’ lives, and then learning not to do that.
2018-04-02.snippet: “The Recovering” is about romanticizing the “unhinged sparks of luminous chaos” in artists’ lives, and then learning not to do that.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: It’s possible to imagine the screenplay Aaron Sorkin would make from Leslie Jamison’s memoir “The Recovering: Intoxication and Its Aftermath.” It would be a bit like “The Social Network,” but instead of rejection its themes would largely be of acceptance.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Leslie Jamison’s Memoir Finds Its Footing in Sobriety

2018-04-02.abstract: The Kremlin said it hoped President Trump would follow through on his proposal for such a session, made before last week’s tit-for-tat expulsion of diplomats.
2018-04-02.snippet: The Kremlin said it hoped President Trump would follow through on his proposal for such a session, made before last week’s tit-for-tat expulsion of diplomats.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia sought to move beyond last week’s diplomatic confrontation with the West on Monday by pressing President Trump for a White House meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin that would undercut the perception that the angry reaction to the poisoning of a former Russian spy in Britain has left it isolated from the international community.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Russia Presses Trump for White House Meeting With Putin

2018-04-02.abstract: A festival featuring 100 chefs, food vendors and restaurants hits the Citi Field parking lot on April 28 and 29.
2018-04-02.snippet: A festival featuring 100 chefs, food vendors and restaurants hits the Citi Field parking lot on April 28 and 29.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: An enormous, globally diverse food festival called World’s Fare, which is meant to recall the world’s fairs that were held in Flushing, Queens, decades ago, will move into the parking lot of Citi Field this month. Some culinary heavy-hitters like Claus Meyer, Jessica B. Harris and the street food expert K.F. Seetoh of Singapore are helping to set the lineup of 100 or so chefs, food vendors and restaurants that will participate. Craft breweries, art and music are part of it. Tickets, from $19 to $199 are now available: World’s Fare, April 28 and 29, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m., Citi Field, 123-01 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, Queens; theworldsfare.nyc.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Another World’s Fair Heads to Queens, This One for Foodies

2018-04-02.abstract: Delmonico’s will offer a special menu to mark the 150th anniversary of the day it welcomed women unescorted by men.
2018-04-02.snippet: Delmonico’s will offer a special menu to mark the 150th anniversary of the day it welcomed women unescorted by men.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: There was a time when New York was more like Riyadh, in that a woman could not enter restaurants unaccompanied by a man. The rule was followed throughout the country. Then in 1868, Delmonico’s, the historic financial district restaurant, tossed it aside and welcomed women to a luncheon held by the Sorosis Club, a pioneering professional women’s organization. To mark the 150th anniversary of the event, the restaurant will feature a special menu created by Gabrielle Hamilton, the chef and owner of Prune, with dishes like beef bouillon with Madeira, a cheese fritter called Malakoff with salad, soft shell crabs with asparagus and américain sauce, and brûléed rice pudding, which will be served in addition to the regular lunch and dinner menus: Ladies’ Lunch, April 23 through 28, Delmonico’s, 56 Beaver Street (South William Street), 212-509-1144, delmonicosrestaurant.com.
2018-04-02.headline_main: A Historic Women’s Luncheon Celebrates an Anniversary

2018-04-02.abstract: “Pizzapedia: An Illustrated Guide to Everyone’s Favorite Food” by Dan Bransfield is a lighthearted and well-researched guide.
2018-04-02.snippet: “Pizzapedia: An Illustrated Guide to Everyone’s Favorite Food” by Dan Bransfield is a lighthearted and well-researched guide.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Lighthearted yet well researched, this illustrated pizza Baedeker hits the right buttons. After a rundown on the history dating to the Roman era, it highlights pizza’s Neapolitan roots, Margherita of Savoy and the classic pizza named for her, and Lombardi’s in New York in 1905. It shows slices from today’s New York spots, including Di Fara, Emmy Squared and Patsy’s, and signature pizzas from several cities, including Chicago and Detroit. Tools, ingredients and futuristic pizza from drones, robots and vending machines are also covered: “Pizzapedia: An Illustrated Guide to Everyone’s Favorite Food” by Dan Bransfield (Ten Speed Press, $16)
2018-04-02.headline_main: Pizza, From Neapolitan Roots to Delivery Drones

2018-04-02.abstract: For the Bushwick Tea company, its beverage of choice should not take a back seat to coffee.
2018-04-02.snippet: For the Bushwick Tea company, its beverage of choice should not take a back seat to coffee.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Ratesh Chopra, whose fledgling tea company is rooted in Brooklyn, describes it as a “passion project.” Dissatisfied with how tea is often an afterthought where coffee is served, he decided to start his own company. By trial and error, he now has a growing inventory sold online and, increasingly, in local shops. He has eight varieties available online, including the black Brooklyn Breakfast, the well-balanced Moroccan Mint and some for making iced tea, with more to come. The teas are full leaf and come in silky sachets. I’m already hooked on the eye-opening Ginger & Turmeric, at once soothing and bold. Prices start at $12 for 15 tea bags: bushwicktea.com.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Moving Tea to the Forefront in Brooklyn

2018-04-02.abstract: Mr. Couch spent 720 days in jail after killing four people and paralyzing a fifth in a car crash. His defense contended that he was too rich to know right from wrong.
2018-04-02.snippet: Mr. Couch spent 720 days in jail after killing four people and paralyzing a fifth in a car crash. His defense contended that he was too rich to know right from wrong.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Ethan Couch, whose trial for killing four people while driving drunk sparked widespread conversations about the privilege of being raised wealthy, was released from a Texas jail on Monday after nearly two years.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Ethan Couch, ‘Affluenza Teen’ Who Killed 4 While Driving Drunk, Is Freed

2018-04-02.abstract: The Socarrat paella bars serve a tasty version of the drink called the Classico, with juniper berries and bitters.
2018-04-02.snippet: The Socarrat paella bars serve a tasty version of the drink called the Classico, with juniper berries and bitters.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: As we enter gin and tonic season, here’s a new way to enjoy the typical cooler. This version, called the Classico, is served at Socarrat, a group of paella restaurants, Spain being a country that’s mad for gin and tonic. It’s a beauty, served in a big stemmed wine goblet, not the usual highball glass, to give the components more room to mingle. Pour 2 ounces (or maybe more) of gin over ice cubes that half-fill the glass, add eight juniper berries, a couple of dashes of Angostura bitters, and the peel, in strips, of half a lemon. Stir well to chill, top with four ounces of cold high-quality tonic water, stir again and enjoy the sunset.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Just in Time for Gin and Tonic Season

2018-04-02.abstract: Hours after the Yankees called off their home opener because of a spring snow, the Mets did the same with their night game against Philadelphia.
2018-04-02.snippet: Hours after the Yankees called off their home opener because of a spring snow, the Mets did the same with their night game against Philadelphia.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Hours after the Yankees postponed their home opener on Monday because of an early-spring snowstorm, the Mets did the same with their 7 p.m. game against the Philadelphia Phillies.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Mets-Phillies Postponed by Snow

2018-04-02.abstract: New York City got several inches of snow, but officials decided against suspending alternate-side parking rules.
2018-04-02.snippet: New York City got several inches of snow, but officials decided against suspending alternate-side parking rules.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Snow in April was already a dispiriting development, but some New Yorkers had more bad news on Monday: They had to move their cars.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Drivers Fume Over Parking Rules During Snowstorm

2018-04-02.abstract: Mr. White’s latest debuted at the top of the Billboard album chart with help from a ticket bundle and 27,000 copies sold as vinyl LPs.

2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: The top of the Billboard album chart over the last couple of weeks has been a tale of two formats: streaming and sales.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Sales, Not Streams, Propel Jack White’s ‘Boarding House Reach’ to No. 1

2018-04-02.abstract: Benefits were held for the MCC Theater, Diffa and Poets & Writers.
2018-04-02.snippet: Benefits were held for the MCC Theater, Diffa and Poets & Writers.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Benefits were held for the MCC Theater, Diffa and Poets & Writers.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Spring Gala Season Warms Up

2018-04-02.abstract: For many women who are now letting go of their wigs and weaves, hair loss is no small problem. There are ways to conceal it.
2018-04-02.snippet: For many women who are now letting go of their wigs and weaves, hair loss is no small problem. There are ways to conceal it.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: When Jasmine Collins, a hairstylist in the Atlanta area, turns her clients around to face themselves in the mirror, it’s often the first time they have seen their own hair styled in years, maybe decades.
2018-04-02.headline_main: What Black Women Need to Know About Hair Loss

2018-04-02.abstract: Critics say a new series, “The Mechanism,” about a corruption scandal, is rife with inaccuracies, stirring polarized debate.
2018-04-02.snippet: Critics say a new series, “The Mechanism,” about a corruption scandal, is rife with inaccuracies, stirring polarized debate.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A new Netflix series about a sprawling corruption investigation has muscled its way into Brazil’s heated politics, outraging supporters of a leftist former president who is trying to make a comeback and stirring debate about how closely a docudrama should adhere to the facts.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Latest Uproar in Brazil’s Raw Political Debate: A Netflix Series

2018-04-02.abstract: They’re subject to rules on etiquette and hygiene, including shaving techniques. Panthers cheerleaders must leave the stadium to change into their personal clothes.
2018-04-02.snippet: They’re subject to rules on etiquette and hygiene, including shaving techniques. Panthers cheerleaders must leave the stadium to change into their personal clothes.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Cheerleaders for the Carolina Panthers, known as the TopCats, must arrive at the stadium on game days at least five hours before kickoff. Body piercings and tattoos must be removed or covered. Water breaks can be taken only when the Panthers are on offense. TopCats must leave the stadium to change into their personal attire.
2018-04-02.headline_main: No Sweatpants in Public: Inside the Rule Books for N.F.L. Cheerleaders

2018-04-02.abstract: The stock market continued to plunge Monday, as investors were unnerved by the unpredictable White House. Stocks are now down 4 percent this year.
2018-04-02.snippet: The stock market continued to plunge Monday, as investors were unnerved by the unpredictable White House. Stocks are now down 4 percent this year.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: The Trump Bump is becoming the Trump Slump.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Markets That Climbed the Trump Bump Are Tumbling Down From It

2018-04-02.abstract: Steve Smith, one of the country’s most revered sportsmen, admits his role in a ball-tampering scheme, prompting national discussion and soul-searching.
2018-04-02.snippet: Steve Smith, one of the country’s most revered sportsmen, admits his role in a ball-tampering scheme, prompting national discussion and soul-searching.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: It is as if Lionel Messi or LeBron James were banned for a year for cheating. But in this case the superstar is Steve Smith, one of the best cricketers in the world and the captain of the national team in Australia, where fair play is prized and cricket is a national obsession.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Australian Cricket Has Its Own Deflategate, and a Nation Reels

2018-04-02.abstract: An agreement struck with the U.N. would have sent half the migrants to the West and let the rest stay, but the prime minister’s right flank revolted.
2018-04-02.snippet: An agreement struck with the U.N. would have sent half the migrants to the West and let the rest stay, but the prime minister’s right flank revolted.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In a head-spinning turnaround, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel announced on Monday that he had reached an extraordinary deal with the United Nations refugee agency to resettle thousands of African asylum seekers in Western countries. Within hours Mr. Netanyahu suspended the deal after coming under heavy criticism from his coalition partners.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Israeli Leader Is Forced to Retreat on African Migrant Deal

2018-04-02.abstract: Seven artists have been selected to interpret Peanuts characters for a public art project in New York and six other cities.
2018-04-02.snippet: Seven artists have been selected to interpret Peanuts characters for a public art project in New York and six other cities.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: Kenny Scharf’s oozing, vividly colored cartoon figures have covered billboards in downtown Manhattan for decades. Now, his whimsical psychedelia will appear in New York in the forms of Charlie Brown, Snoopy and the rest of the Peanuts gang, as part of a new public art project bringing Charles M. Schulz’s characters to cities around the world.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Good Grief, Charlie Brown! You’re Graffiti

2018-04-02.abstract: The appointments illustrate the church’s focus on international recruitment as membership in the United States levels off.
2018-04-02.snippet: The appointments illustrate the church’s focus on international recruitment as membership in the United States levels off.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: For the first time in its nearly 200-year history, the Mormon Church on Saturday appointed a person of color  into the upper echelons of its leadership, a group that has previously been occupied by white men.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Mormon Church Selects 2 Senior Leaders, and Neither Is a White American

2018-04-02.abstract: Questions about Sinclair’s size and handling of local broadcasters have been raised for more than a year.
2018-04-02.snippet: Questions about Sinclair’s size and handling of local broadcasters have been raised for more than a year.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: The internet lit up over the weekend after videos showed dozens of local newscasters across the country using the same script to criticize the news industry. The newscasters said they were “concerned about the troubling trend of irresponsible, one-sided news stories plaguing our country.”
2018-04-02.headline_main: Sinclair Videos Renew Debate Over Media Ownership

2018-04-02.abstract: Repertorio Español delivers an intimate, transporting adaptation of the Gabriel García Márquez novella.
2018-04-02.snippet: Repertorio Español delivers an intimate, transporting adaptation of the Gabriel García Márquez novella.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: The grandest presence onstage at Repertorio Español belongs to the smallest creature there: a handsome rooster with luxurious plumage in fiery tones and a strikingly comfortable rapport with his principal scene partner.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Review: Betting on a Rooster in ‘No One Writes to the Colonel’

2018-04-02.abstract: FX’s kaleidoscopic superhero psychodrama keeps trying to top itself, which isn’t a game you can play forever.
2018-04-02.snippet: FX’s kaleidoscopic superhero psychodrama keeps trying to top itself, which isn’t a game you can play forever.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: The second season of FX’s series “Legion” begins on Tuesday with a voice-over intoning: “You’re inside the maze now. You can’t escape.” It’s a description of insanity. It’s also, of course, a reference to the experience of watching “Legion.”
2018-04-02.headline_main: Review: ‘Legion’ Resumes. Hold On to Your Brain.

2018-04-02.abstract: The group Mercy Corps sees possibility and not doom for Kenya’s herders and farmers.
2018-04-02.snippet: The group Mercy Corps sees possibility and not doom for Kenya’s herders and farmers.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
2018-04-02.headline_main: A Food Crisis and Climate Change

2018-04-02.abstract: Season 1 of the “X-Men” spinoff was a trippy, multilayered romp through the psyche of its protagonist. Fuzzy on the details? We’re here to help.
2018-04-02.snippet: Season 1 of the “X-Men” spinoff was a trippy, multilayered romp through the psyche of its protagonist. Fuzzy on the details? We’re here to help.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: “Legion,” FX’s funky and playful Marvel adaptation from Noah Hawley (who also adapted “Fargo” for the network) returns for its second season on Tuesday at 10 p.m., with some high expectations to meet. Its first season, best summarized as “X-Men” meets “Shock Corridor” by way of “Inception,” was invigoratingly unpredictable, mixing the expected superhero mythmaking with wildly experimental cinematography, anything-goes storytelling, and frequent, brassy musical breaks.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Ready for Season 2 of ‘Legion’? Here’s What to Remember.

2018-04-02.abstract: Tate Modern focuses on a single year, with more than 100 paintings, sculpture and drawings. This was a fraction of the artist’s prodigious output.
2018-04-02.snippet: Tate Modern focuses on a single year, with more than 100 paintings, sculpture and drawings. This was a fraction of the artist’s prodigious output.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the sun set on the last day of 1932, President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt waited to take office, while American banks continued to buckle. The last chancellor of Weimar Germany sat in a Rococo palace in Berlin; the last emperor of China was installed on a puppet throne in Manchukuo. The globe was agitated, and art was not exempt. The Nazis forced the Bauhaus out of Dessau in 1932, and in the same year the Soviet Union dissolved independent artists’ unions and promulgated the single style of socialist realism.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Picasso in 1932: Ingenious, Exhausting, Relentless

2018-04-02.abstract: The agency announced a plan to relax Obama-era greenhouse gas rules and signaled that it aimed to make California, which sets its own standards, fall in line.
2018-04-02.snippet: The agency announced a plan to relax Obama-era greenhouse gas rules and signaled that it aimed to make California, which sets its own standards, fall in line.
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency on Monday took steps to challenge California’s decades-old right to set its own air pollution rules, setting up a showdown between the federal government and a state that has emerged as a bulwark against the Trump administration’s policies.
2018-04-02.headline_main: Calling Car Pollution Standards ‘Too High,’ E.P.A. Sets Up Fight With California

2018-04-02.abstract: A reader says she relies on “a free and independent press to guide us through these troubled times.”
2018-04-02.snippet: A reader says she relies on “a free and independent press to guide us through these troubled times.”
2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

For more than a decade, their 140-square-mile strip has been blockaded by Israel and Egypt, sharply restricting the flow of goods and people. Indeed, many Gazans have never left the enclave, a grim measure of their prolonged isolation.

He was 87.

2018-04-02.abstract: The obituary, which was published on April 5, 1968, celebrated the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. as a prophet of a crusade for racial equality and a voice of anguish for millions of people.

2018-04-02.lead_paragraph: To many millions of American Negroes, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was the prophet of their crusade for racial equality. He was their voice of anguish, their eloquence in humiliation, their battle cry for human dignity. He forged for them the weapons of nonviolence that withstood and blunted the ferocity of segregation.

Clarke’s film “2001: A Space Odyssey,” which turns 50 this week, that the disc-shaped card commemorating the German Film Museum’s new exhibition on the film is wordless, but instantly recognizable. Its face features the Cyclopean red eye of the HAL-9000 supercomputer; nothing more needs saying.

2018-04-03.abstract: Baklava and mille-feuille come together in this chewy, buttery, sweet and creamy morsel.
2018-04-03.snippet: Baklava and mille-feuille come together in this chewy, buttery, sweet and creamy morsel.
2018-04-03.lead_paragraph: When my chin is down, my eyes are closed and my hands are cupped over my ears, it’s a sure sign that I’m tasting. I know how odd I look, but the momentary calm helps me concentrate on flavors when there’s a new recipe at hand or a complex ingredient. I always taste chocolate this way, and every once in a while I lock myself in my sensory cocoon because I’ve come upon something unusual that I want to get to know better. A couple of months ago in Paris, it was a pastry from a new, strikingly designed patisserie in the Marais, Maison Aleph.
2018-04-03.headline_main: A New Pastry Layers Tastes of France and Syria

2018-04-03.abstract: Physicians grapple with the extraordinary cost of medical care in America.
2018-04-03.snippet: Physicians grapple with the extraordinary cost of medical care in America.
2018-04-03.lead_paragraph: To understand something about the spiraling cost of health care in the United States, we might begin with a typical conundrum: Imagine a 60-something man — a nonsmoker, overweight, with diabetes — who has just survived a heart attack. Perhaps he had an angioplasty, with the placement of a stent, to open his arteries. The doctor’s job is to keep the vessels open. She has two choices of medicines to reduce the risk for a second heart attack. There’s Plavix, a tried-and-tested blood thinner, that prevents clot formation; the generic version of the drug costs as little as 25 cents a pill. And there’s Brilinta, a newer medicine that is also effective in clot prevention; it costs about $6.50 a pill — 25 times as much.
2018-04-03.headline_main: Can Doctors Choose Between Saving Lives and Saving a Fortune?

2018-04-03.abstract: Debating for sport used to be tolerated online — but that was before you could argue with everybody, all the time.
2018-04-03.snippet: Debating for sport used to be tolerated online — but that was before you could argue with everybody, all the time.
2018-04-03.lead_paragraph: In 1990, a lawyer named Mike Godwin made what would become a famous observation: As an online discussion grows longer, the probability that someone will draw a comparison involving Hitler or the Nazis approaches 100 percent. The internet has changed pretty significantly since then; its fascists, for instance, are a lot less hypothetical. But a more important development might be that the whole concept of “online discussion” has been radically reshaped by the technologies that drive it.
2018-04-03.headline_main: Why Have We Soured on the ‘Devil’s Advocate’?

2018-04-03.abstract: As China’s Xi Jinping consolidates power, owners of Hong Kong bookstores trafficking in banned books find themselves playing a very dangerous game.
2018-04-03.snippet: As China’s Xi Jinping consolidates power, owners of Hong Kong bookstores trafficking in banned books find themselves playing a very dangerous game.
2018-04-03.lead_paragraph: When the police officer didn’t laugh, Lam Wing-kee knew he was in trouble. In his two decades as owner and manager of Hong Kong’s Causeway Bay Books, Lam had honed a carefully nonchalant routine when caught smuggling books into mainland China: apologize, claim ignorance, offer a cigarette to the officers, crack a joke. For most of his career, the routine was foolproof.
2018-04-03.headline_main: The Case of Hong Kong’s Missing Booksellers

2018-04-03.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to pass on information about a deceptive ex-spouse, a possible insurance fraud and more.
2018-04-03.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to pass on information about a deceptive ex-spouse, a possible insurance fraud and more.
2018-04-03.lead_paragraph: My sister-in-law was married to a man who looked good on paper and who was very charming. She found out after they were married that he lied to her about his employment history and history of drug and alcohol abuse, as well as about his finances. He had a breakdown soon after their child was born and received a diagnosis for a serious mental illness. When he was unmedicated, he was violent toward her. Even on medication, he has shown no remorse about the destruction he caused. He admitted that he spent the year before meeting her rehearsing his “story” so he could meet someone like her. He can still seem charming and, to an outsider, like a functioning adult.
2018-04-03.headline_main: Should the New Girlfriend of an Awful Ex-Husband Be Warned?

2018-04-03.abstract: A selection of books published this week; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
2018-04-03.snippet: A selection of books published this week; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
2018-04-03.lead_paragraph: POST TRAUMATIC HOOD DISORDER By David Tomas Martinez. (Sarabande, paper, $15.95.) In his second collection, Martinez has fun with the high-low mash-up that characterizes so much poetry today — one poem here is called “Footnoting Biggie Lyrics Like ‘Why Christmas Missed Us’” — but he also includes tender love poems and searching personal reminiscences. THE BLACK BEAR INSIDE ME By Robin Becker. (Pittsburgh, paper, $15.95.) These lilting, observational poems often invoke music: ballroom dancing, a Beethoven quartet, Scottish songs. One, “Reading Music,” concludes, “I remember when at five the marks on / the page became a story.” CENZONTLE By Marcelo Hernandez Castillo. (BOA Editions, paper, $16.) The title of Castillo’s debut means “mockingbird,” and birds flit in and out of these poems, singing our world back at us. Castillo embraces an expansive ambiguity — of language, of gender, of nationality — that can sound celebratory and mournful at once. EYE LEVEL By Jenny Xie. (Graywolf, paper, $16.) “Funny, the way we come to understand a place by wanting to escape it,” Xie writes, and the poems in her crystalline debut (with titles including “Rootless,” “Borderless,” “Displacement”) are ever alert to the complex relationship between geography and the self. IS THAT THE SOUND OF A PIANO COMING FROM SEVERAL HOUSES DOWN? By Noah Eli Gordon. (Solid Objects, $20.) The prose poems that make up the bulk of this slim book, all of them called “The Problem,” resemble absurdist flash fiction, disrupting reality through juxtaposition and non sequitur.
2018-04-03.headline_main: New & Noteworthy

2018-04-03.abstract: The pre-Incan ruins of Kuélap share similarities with their more famous cousin. But getting there can be a herculean effort.
2018-04-03.snippet: The pre-Incan ruins of Kuélap share similarities with their more famous cousin. But getting there can be a herculean effort.
2018-04-03.lead_paragraph: I was standing in a cloud forest in northern Peru, 10,000 feet above sea level. Quiet cloaked the more than 400 cylindrical homes and ceremonial buildings that make up the most important settlement of the Chachapoyas, or “Cloud Warrior” culture. Farther out were limestone walls up to 65 feet high. Tropical greenery sprang through cracks in the stone, while red bromeliads clung to moss-covered trees. In every direction was a backdrop of patchwork farmland clinging to the sides of mountains, above the Utcubamba River Valley.
2018-04-03.headline_main: The 52 Places Traveler: In Peru, a Still-Hidden Alternative to Machu Picchu

2018-04-03.snippet: Volunteers are needed for recovery efforts in the Caribbean. Resorts, cruise lines and other organizations are offering special programs.

In March, Ms. Hepburn decided to go to St. John solo to volunteer, joining projects cleaning up trails in a national park, painting at a local school and assisting at an animal shelter.
2018-04-03.headline_main: How Travelers Can Help Hurricane-Damaged Islands

2018-04-03.abstract: A dystopian show that will make you feel better about your own life.
2018-04-03.snippet: A dystopian show that will make you feel better about your own life.
2018-04-03.lead_paragraph: I cannot watch “Black Mirror” anymore. Its metaphors have grown stale, its winks are now klaxons and its messages — once distorted and eerie — now land with a thud. The same holds true for most so-called “prestige” television, from the violent, misogynist dystopia of “The Handmaid’s Tale” to the violent, misogynist dystopia of “Westworld.” They feel inevitable and manipulative, and watching them does nothing but intensify my already simmering anxieties — which I suspect is the point. So nowadays, when the kitchen is clean and the cats are fed and my brain is on its downward spiral toward sleep, all I want to do is sink into the couch and turn on “House Hunters,” a show about a specific kind of darkness I have complete control in avoiding. It provides all the thrill of a dystopian hellscape with none of the fear.
2018-04-03.headline_main: Letter of Recommendation: ‘House Hunters’

2018-04-03.snippet: Seasonal and new American in Long Island City, Queens; and more restaurant news.
2018-04-03.lead_paragraph: BLEECKER STREET LUNCHEONETTE Here’s an exceptional restaurant story at a time when rent increases keep turning dining rooms into empty storefronts. One such victim was Risotteria in the West Village, which Joseph Pace, an experienced chef with French training, opened in 1999 and closed two years ago. He and his wife, Adrienne Pace, left New York to travel and returned to find the city welcoming a spicier, more global, vegetable-based cuisine and Mr. Pace’s former landlord “ready to deal,” as he put it. So he is now back in his old space, and has opened this all-day restaurant serving breakfast items like a poached egg lentil bowl and eggs baked with the green Yemeni hot sauce called zhug. Hefty sandwiches on bread that’s gluten-free or not, salads and main courses (served after noon) that include skirt steak, mac and cheese and leg of lamb with kofta seasonings, round out a menu that unites comfort food and Middle Eastern seasoning. The drinks list (beer and wine only) is modest in length and price. Mr. Pace’s take on the “all day” restaurant is simply done, with bare tables and wood floors: 270 Bleecker Street (Morton Street), 917-261-6479, bleeckerluncheonette.com.
2018-04-03.headline_main: Comfort Food With Middle Eastern Spices at Bleecker Street Luncheonette

2018-04-04.abstract: A home improvement on a classic Chinese-American takeout dish.
2018-04-04.snippet: A home improvement on a classic Chinese-American takeout dish.
2018-04-04.lead_paragraph: According to most estimates, there are more than 40,000 Chinese restaurants in the United States, and it seems as if you can find some version of beef and broccoli at almost all of them: velvety wok-fried meat in brown sauce, served in a forest of green. The dish has been part of the Chinese-American restaurant-food canon since at least the 1950s, a few decades after broccoli first rode to popular heights on the backs of the southern Italian immigrants who championed it on our shores. The dish is a standard at high-end restaurants and scruffy takeout shops alike, wherever there is a market for the sweet-salty-crisp flavors that Americans claim as a birthright.
2018-04-04.headline_main: The Best Beef and Broccoli, No Delivery Required

2018-04-04.abstract: The chief executive of 23andMe on paternity testing, A-Rod and Facebook.
2018-04-04.snippet: The chief executive of 23andMe on paternity testing, A-Rod and Facebook.
2018-04-04.lead_paragraph: Your company, 23andMe, does DNA tests that can tell you what countries your ancestors were from or what genetic diseases you may have or, most important, whether you suffer from “asparagus pee.” But your ultimate ambition is to take data culled from your customers’ DNA and use it to find cures and develop drugs. Why? The health care ecosystem that exists today is a $3-trillion-a-year economy and no one makes money if you stay healthy. There’s very little money that goes into prevention programs, and I think that’s not reflective of what you and I want. What we really care about most is not “How do I manage my Alzheimer’s?” but “How do I never get it in the first place?”
2018-04-04.headline_main: Anne Wojcicki Wants to Be Healthy at 100

2018-04-04.abstract: Selected by Terrance Hayes.
2018-04-04.snippet: Selected by Terrance Hayes.
2018-04-04.lead_paragraph: Maybe you will say this “Game of Thrones”-inspired poem is mere play. Play is very worthwhile. Play with the multiple meanings of a word like “stark,” for example. Play with the sounds bouncing around: “stark” to “stock,” “famish” to “fathered.” When the first-person “I” enters the poem, play acquires a wonderful intimacy. “I would meet you upon this” is a private, possibly playful, promise. The last line is a song. Selected by Terrance Hayes
2018-04-04.headline_main: Poem: I Want to Be Stark [Like]

2018-04-04.abstract: Research manufacturer and model. Get a stethoscope. If opening for others, let them open the door first.
2018-04-04.snippet: Research manufacturer and model. Get a stethoscope. If opening for others, let them open the door first.
2018-04-04.lead_paragraph: “It takes 20 years to get good at it,” says Francesco Therisod, 71, who has been a safecracker in Providence, R.I., for nearly 40 years. To know what you’re up against, research the safe’s manufacturer, make, model and materials. At a minimum, you’ll need a drill; diamond and tungsten carbide drill bits, capable of boring into reinforced metals; an optical device called a borescope; and a stethoscope.
2018-04-04.headline_main: How to Crack a Safe

2018-04-04.abstract: The tutors deal not in plain-old schoolwork or straight-up counseling, but in a blend of the two, offering academic and psychological support, at a price.
2018-04-04.snippet: The tutors deal not in plain-old schoolwork or straight-up counseling, but in a blend of the two, offering academic and psychological support, at a price.
2018-04-04.lead_paragraph: On a recent Sunday, Bari Hillman, who works during the week as a clinical psychologist at a New York mental health clinic, was perched at a clear, plastic desk inside a 16-year-old’s Manhattan bedroom, her shoeless feet resting on a fluffy white rug. Dr. Hillman was helping a private school sophomore manage her outsize worry over a long-term writing project. The student had taped the project outline on the wall above the desk, at Dr. Hillman’s prodding. It was designed to serve both as a reminder that the project was due, and an empowering indicator of progress.
2018-04-04.headline_main: Homework Therapists’ Job: Help Solve Math Problems, and Emotional Ones

2018-04-04.snippet: Global warming is causing spring to arrive early and autumn to come late in many places, and not all species are adapting at the same rate.
2018-04-04.lead_paragraph: Every year, as the seasons change, a complex ballet unfolds around the world. Trees in the Northern Hemisphere leaf out in the spring as frost recedes. Caterpillars hatch to gorge on leaves. Bees and butterflies emerge to pollinate flowers. Birds leave the Southern Hemisphere and fly thousands of miles to lay eggs and feast on insects in the north.
2018-04-04.headline_main: 5 Plants and Animals Utterly Confused by Climate Change

2018-04-04.abstract: Ms. Wood, who has testified before Congress about surviving rape, discusses the power of going public in the #MeToo era and how her TV character inspired her.
2018-04-04.snippet: Ms. Wood, who has testified before Congress about surviving rape, discusses the power of going public in the #MeToo era and how her TV character inspired her.
2018-04-04.lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — When Evan Rachel Wood needs a jolt of confidence, she puts on a certain playlist, a compendium of feminist anthems and feisty classics — “I Will Survive,” “These Boots Are Made for Walking,” Tina Turner, Pat Benatar, some head-whipping grunge and hip-hop. It was piping through her house here one chilly afternoon last month. Ms. Wood, the actress and musician, had just put herself through an emotional wringer: She testified before Congress, in unflinching terms, about being a survivor of sexual violence, then jetted to Los Angeles to perform songs by David Bowie, her musical idol, with his bandmates.
2018-04-04.headline_main: Evan Rachel Wood Turns Her Trauma Into Good. On ‘Westworld’ and in Life.

2018-04-04.lead_paragraph: We first meet Joe — his face shadowed, his breathing heavy — as he cleans up after a night of work. The tools of his trade include a roll of duct tape and a ball-peen hammer smeared with blood, which might lead us to believe that we have entered the world of a serial killer. The girl whose picture is briefly glimpsed might be his latest victim. An aura of dread and violence is summoned by the off-center images, the syncopations of the editing and the relentless hum and throb of Jonny Greenwood’s score.
